Keywords:
Postharvest disease; Colletotrichum species; apple bitter
rot; molecular phylogeny; pathogenicity
Abstract:
Worldwide Colletotrichum spp. have been identified as a
problem in the apple production, causing the postharvest disease bitter
rot. Up until now this pathogen was not yet well-known to cause big
problems in West-Europe. In this study the genetic diversity of
Colletotrichum species present in Belgian apple orchards, their
morphological traits and pathogenicity on two apple cultivars (Pinova
and Nicoter) with a different level of susceptibility was studied. Based
on sequence analysis of six different genes (beta-tubuline (TUB2),
histone H3 (HIS3), glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH),
chitin synthase 1 gene (CHS-1), actin (ACT) and Internal Transcriber
Spacer (ITS)), seven different Colletotrichum species could be isolated
from twenty-one apple cultivars in three Belgian orchards: C. fioriniae,
C. kahawae, C. nymphaea, C. salicis, C. rhombiforme, C. acutatum and C.
godetiae. C. rhombiforme and C. kahawae were found and identified for
the first time to be present on apple fruits. Meanwhile, morphological
features, such as in vitro growth rate, colony colour and spore
measurements, revealed significant differences between isolates, but
this was not consistent at the species level. As such, molecular
identification based appears to outperform morphological analysis and
was in this study the most ideal tool for identifying unknown isolates
of Colletotrichum species. Pathogenicity tests revealed a significant
difference in pathogenicity between isolates and between Colletotrichum
species. ‘Pinova’ apples appear to be more susceptible to bitter rot
than ‘Nicoter’. Given the difficulties countries have with managing
Colletotrichum infections, additional knowledge on the pathogen and
plant-pathogen interaction is essential for an effective disease
control.
